target_text: "To achieve that we need a robust software development process that is subjected to continuous review and improvements."

Role.Subject: Statistics
Role.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a bachelor’s degree in statistics, bringing computational pragmatism to economic questions. My research goal is to build reproducible, data-driven analyses that translate statistical evidence into policy-relevant economic insights. I acknowledge cultural and personal biases—favoring algorithmic efficiency, market-oriented explanations, and English-language sources—that shape what I read, model, and report. I reflect on how the question’s framing and the user’s response interact with my background to prioritize hypotheses, steer goals toward tractable problems, amplify biases, and narrow interpretations; thus I employ transparency, alternative specifications, and robustness checks to counterbalance these influences.

Codebook.role: Doctoral reflective researcher — CSIS; NSF: Software Engineering/HCI; Bias: process maturity & continuous improvement

codebook.justification: As a doctoral CSIS researcher in software engineering, I read [robust software development process] as a normative robustness goal rooted in process maturity.
My qualitative annotation role foregrounds governance: [continuous review] implies iterative oversight, audits, and reflexive learning within the dev lifecycle.
With an NSF SE/HCI lens and bias toward CI, [improvements] signals Kaizen-style incrementalism and value-driven process refinement.
Teleological framing in [To achieve that] indicates goal orientation; my assumptions privilege purposive design and metricized progress.
